text.0: sprung from tall trees on windy heights these rollers transport me as they turn upon the table.
text.1: dearer to me the die that never slumbers than the deep draught of mujavans own soma.
text.2: she never vexed me nor was angry with me but to my friends and me was ever gracious.
text.3: for the dies sake whose single point is final mine own devoted wife i alienated.
text.4: my wife holds me aloof her mother hates me the wretched man finds none to give him comfort.
text.5: as of a costly horse grown old and feeble i find not any profit of the gamester.
text.6: others caress the wife of him whose riches the die hath coveted that rapid courser.
text.7: of him speak father mother brothers saying we know him not bind him and take him with you.
text.8: when i resolve to play with these no longer my friends depart from me and leave me lonely.
text.9: when the brown dice thrown on the board have rattled like a fond girl i seek the place of meeting.
text.10: the gamester seeks the gamblinghouse and wonders his body all afire shall i be lucky.
text.11: still do the dice extend his eager longing staking his gains against his adversary.
text.12: dice verily are armed with goads and drivinghooks deceiving and tormenting causing grievous woe.
text.13: they give frail gifts and then destroy the man who wins thickly anointed with the players fairest good.
text.14: merrily sports their troop the threeandfifty like savitar the god whose ways are faithful.
text.15: they bend not even to the mightys anger the king himself pays homage and reveres them.
text.16: downward they roll and then spring quickly upward and handless force the man with hands to serve them.
text.17: cast on the board like lumps of magic charcoal though cold themselves they burn the heart to ashes.
text.18: the gamblers wife is left forlorn and wretched the mother mourns the son who wanders homeless.
text.19: in constant fear in debt and seeking riches he goes by night unto the home of others.
text.20: sad is the gambler when he sees a matron anothers wife and his wellordered dwelling.
text.21: he yokes the brown steeds in the early morning and when the fire is cold sinks down an outcast.
text.22: to the great captain of your mighty army who hath become the hosts imperial leader.
text.23: to him i show my ten extended fingers i speak the truth no wealth am i withholding.
text.24: play not with dice no cultivate thy cornland enjoy the gain and deem that wealth sufficient.
text.25: there are thy cattle there thy wife o gambler so this good savitar himself hath told me.
text.26: make me your friend show us some little mercy assail us not with your terrific fierceness.
text.27: appeased be your malignity and anger and let the brown dice snare some other captive.
